awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Networks of Support and Solidarity in Carceral Contexts
awd_abstract_narration:
The carceral experience encompasses not only the over two million people currently incarcerated in American prisons, but also those within the broader social, affective, and kin networks with which incarcerated individuals are connected. This doctoral dissertation project seeks to investigate how relationships of solidarity, kinship, and affinity are created, changed, or maintained during imprisonment. In exploring such a question, this research examines how imprisoned people and the people with whom they share close ties manage to build affective networks, bonds of mutuality, and reciprocity within and across prison borders. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project strives to enrich the public's understanding of science and the scientific method by sharing its findings through public-facing venues and organizational dissemination. The project also broadens the participation of historically underrepresented groups in the production of scientific knowledge. 

A core hypothesis of this research is that incarceration impacts the strength of social bonds among imprisoned people and their social networks in ways that parallel the systematicity of chattel slavery. The doctoral student tests this hypothesis through an in-depth, rigorous analysis of archival sources from historical and contemporary epochs. The researcher will complement these data with twelve months of participant observation and approximately seventy-five semi-structured interviews with interlocutors in two organizations that facilitate communications with incarcerated individuals. Thus, while many generative studies insinuate a link between enslavement and imprisonment in the United States, the present study will be one of the first to test a hypothesis about the link with a scientific and ethnographic eye. In so doing, this doctoral dissertation project advances the ascendant, interdisciplinary scholarship that seeks to uncover a usable carceral past in order to better comprehend the scope and scale of the contemporary prison system. The project integrates analysis of archival, sociolegal, and ethnographic data to improve scientific understanding of how people navigate institutional bureaucracies and spatial challenges to forge and maintain affective and kin-based relationships.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the grant funding period, the co-PI completed twelve months of ethnographic and archival research to test two hypotheses established by preliminary reseach. Hypothesis one held that incarceration impacts the social and familial relationships among imprisoned people similar to how chattel slavery impacted the social and familial relationships among enslaved people. Hypothesis two held that these same relationships destabilize the very idea of the prison by creating new ways of understanding space and time.

To test hypothesis one, the co-PI undertook two data collection methods to determine its validity. The first involved archival research that pursued a comparative approach between documents of similar genres (legal, journalistic, and biographical) created in different centuries. In addition to the co-PI's careful reading of these documents, the co-PI augmented these materials with several other primary sources that only became known to the co-PI once in the field. Most notably, these included all issues of the prison-issued magazine that were published between 1990 and 2023 as well as archived versions of websites maintained by the penitentiary and department of correction. Audits, budgets, and maps also came under close scrutiny. Preliminary analyses suggest that the evidence gathered and inspected (thus far) supports hypothesis one, which held that incarceration impacts the social ties of imprisoned people similar to how chattel slavery impacted the social ties of enslaved people. Primary areas of overlap between the areas included methods of discipline (separation, isolation, marked clothing), forced labor under the threat of punishment, and the regulation of spiritual practices, the latter of which only surfaced on the pages of the prison's magazine. Another addition to the methods for hypothesis one included detailed observations of the prison museum, which the co-PI theorized would be an optimal site to take note of any references the prison makes between its own approach compared to the approach of people who operated it as a plantation. From all of these sources, an early conclusion is that the social experience of an imprisoned person closely aligns with the social experience of an enslaved person. This is not to imply that imprisonment is equivalent to enslavement. It is simply to say, preliminarily, that the two hold an undeniable relationship, the evidence for which emerges from the claims made by the people imprisoned/enslaved.

To test hypothesis two, the co-PI completed participation observation within the first intended field site, a bus service, but made a change to the second intended field site, a pen pal organization, due to a temporary pause in the group's activity during the course of fieldwork. In its place, the co-PI pivoted to a backup plan of observing publicly available parole hearings of imprisoned people seeking relief from their sentences. At the first site, the co-PI participated in twelve total bus rides (averaging 12 hours each) and participated in the organization's core fundraiser. Additionally as planned the co-PI attended the prison's festival on three separate occasions for a total of ten hours. Due to security concerns, only a select number of interviews were conducted. At the second site, the co-PI watched and took detailed notes on thirty-one parole hearings that amounted to roughly forty-five hours. To enrich the data collected at site two, the co-PI also attended public hearings with government officials stating and explaining shifts in policies related to the imprisoned population at the penitentiary. The intention paralled an additional method for hypothesis one, which was to afford as much attention to the state's publicly stated motivations and rationale for pursuing certain actions. While the analysis is still underway, the preliminary finding is that the evidence does not support hypothesis two, which held that social and familial relationships among imprisoned people destabilize the very idea of the prison by creating new ways of understanding space and time. In fact, the opposite might be true: the prison may well weaponize these connections as a way of perpetuating its presence and power.

Overall, this study provides an ethnographic account about the relationship between enslavement and imprisonment. It also forces a reconsideration about the future of reform efforts in the criminal legal system. To that end, the co-PI successfully fulfilled an intention to distribute information from the research to members of the communities directly implicated. Several such public sessions were held in New Orleans during the last month of the fieldwork.
